choices.text: Normal male chromosome Constitution with an end organ defect
Streak gonad and cryptorchid contralateral testis

questions.text: What is the familial syndrome of testicular feminization from the following?
questions.solution:
• MIXED GONADAL DYSGENESIS(choice C)
    • 45,X/46,XY mosaicism or 46,XY phenotype)
    • One gonad is represented by a streak gonad or streak testis and a contralateral testis (that is typically cryptorchid) or bilateral streak testis.
    • Prone to the develop gonadoblastomas, a complication prevented by early removal of the gonads.
  • TRUE HERMAPHRODITES (choice A)
    • Ovotestes containing both ova and immature seminiferous tubules or other combinations of ovary and testis.
    • The most common karyotypes:- 46,XX (60%), 46,XY (12%), and mosaic (28%).
    • Multiple tumors can occur in these gonads.
  • THE FAMILIAL SYNDROME OF TESTICULAR FEMINIZATION (choice B)
    • The most common type of male pseudohermaphroditism
    • Normal male chromosome constitution with an end-organ defect (androgen insensibility).
    • Well-developed female secondary sex characteristics.
    • Presence of vagina, no uterus, and bilateral cryptorchid testes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Testicular Feminisation (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - AIS)

Definition: A genetic disorder where an individual with a 46,XY karyotype has a resistance to androgen action due to mutations in the androgen receptor (AR) gene.

choices.text: The earliest malignant lesion of high grade serous carcinoma
Most common site of involvement is ampulla

questions.text: Which of the following statement is wrong about Serous Tubal Intraepethial Carcinoma (STIC)?
questions.solution:
Non-invasive form (of High grade serous carcinoma) is called Serous Tubal Intraepethial Carcinoma à STIC

  • Usually found at tubo- peritoneal junction
  • Most common finding- Fimbriae (choice B)
  • High N:C ratio, nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, loss of cilia/polarity.
  • High mitotic activity
  • Even though "intraepithelial" it can still metastasize /spread to the ovary and peritoneum (I.e. it's essentially still malignant) and cause high grade serous carcinoma (choice A)
  • IHC: p53 mutant (choice C) ; ki67 >10% (choice D)
  • Increased risk with BRCA mutation àoften get prophylactic bilatersl salpingo-oophorectomy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: STIC is a precursor lesion for high-grade serous carcinoma (HGSC) of the ovary and peritoneum, located in the fallopian tube epithelium.

It represents early, non-invasive carcinoma with malignant potential.

Most commonly arises in the fimbrial end of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: A 43 years old female having ascites and adnexal mass. Hysterectomy specimen reveals following gross and microscopic images from the mass of right ovary. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Transitional/Brenner tumor

  • Brenner tumor- benign
    • Transitional epithelium, resembling urothelium of GU tract
    • Older adults
    • Small, unilateral, solid, firm mass with small cysts
    • Nests of Transitional epithelium/urothelium set in dense fibrous stroma
    • Mucinous differentiation can be common.
    • Calcification±
    • IHC: Urothelial immunophenotype (+p63, p40, ck7, GATA3, Uroplakin III, thrombomodulin)
  • Borderline brenner tumor: Brenner tumor with papillary areas resembling non-invasive, low-grade urothelial carcinoma
    • No destructive stromal invasion
  • Malignant Brenner tumor: Brenner tumor with Papillary areas resemble invasive high grade urothelial carcinoma
    • Stromal invasion+

Histologically, there are nests of transitional epithelial (urothelial) cells with longitudinal nuclear grooves (coffee bean nuclei) lying in abundant fibrous stroma.

The coffee bean nuclei are the nuclear grooves exceptionally pathognomonic to the sex cord stromal tumour, the ovarian granulosa cell tumour, with the fluid-filled spaces Call-Exner bodies between the granulosa cells.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Brenner tumours are an uncommon subtype of the surface epithelial-stromal tumour group of ovarian neoplasms. The majority are benign, but some can be malignant.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brenner_tumour

choices.text: 30% of HSIL regress after treatment
60% of HSIL progress to carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about low grade squamous Intraepethial lesion (LSIL) and high grade squamous Intraepethial lesion (HSIL)?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of squamous Intraepethial lesion (SIL) is based on:

  • Nuclear atypia characterized by nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia(dark staining), coarse chromatin granules, and variation in nuclear size and shape.
  • The nuclear changes are often accompanied by cytoplasmic "halos." Nuclear alterations associated with perinuclear halos are termed KOILOCYTIC ATYPIA.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The grading of SIL into low or high grade is based on EXPANSION OF THE IMMATURE CELL LAYER FROM ITS NORMAL, BASAL LOCATION.

If the immature squamous cells are confined to the lower one-third of the epithelium, the lesion is called LSIL; if they expand to the upper two-thirds of the epithelial thickness, it is called HSIL.

choices.text: Oval to round to straight endometrial glands

questions.text: What is the most prominent change seen in late secretory phase?
questions.solution:
Endometrial cycle & Dating


KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Histological Features in late secretory phase of menstrual cycle :

  • Glands:
    • Highly coiled ("saw-toothed" appearance).
    • Glandular secretions rich in glycogen and glycoproteins are present in the lumen, essential for nourishing the embryo.
  • Stroma:
    • Edematous due to increased vascular permeability.
    • Stromal cells begin predecidualization, transforming into polygonal cells with large nuclei.
  • Spiral Arteries:
    • Prominent and coiled, extending deeper into the stroma to support implantation.

Reference:

https://embryology.med.unsw.edu.au/embryology/index.php?title=Menstrual_Cycle_-_Histology.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman had a 12-cm polypoid vulvar mass excised.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
DEEP (AGGRESSIVE) ANGIOMYXOMA

  • Benign, but tendency to recur after incomplete recurrence
  • Large mass (>5 cm), poorly circumscribed, infiltrative.
  • Gross: Gelatinous consistency
  • Often present as a cyst in reproductive age
  • Microscopic features :- Low- grade, hypocellular.
    • Composed of small bland spindled cells with scant cytoplasm.
    • Numerous blood vessels of varying sizes, including thin walled capillary like and thick walled arteries with radiating perivascular smooth muscle
    • Invades fat and muscle
    • Extravasated rbcs
    • No mitotic activity of atypia.
  • IHC: ER+, PR+, Desmin+/-, CD34
  • Molecular- HMGA2 rearrangements
  • Treatment- Complete surgical resection, most people treated with first surgery.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Aggressive angiomyxoma is an infiltrative spindle cell neoplasm arising in the soft tissues of the lower genital tract, perineum and pelvis; approximately 30% recur locally but distant metastasis is exceptionally rare

Reference: https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/vulvaaggressiveangiomyxoma.html

questions.text: Which statement from the following is TRUE about HPV independent squamous cell carcinoma of vulva?
questions.solution:
An invasive epithelial tumor composed of squamous cells with varying degrees of differentiation.

Derived from HSIL (HPV associated) or Differentiated VIN (HPV- independent)

  • Most common vulvar malignancy- SCC
  • Most important factor determining outcomeà Lymph nodes status
  • Most important factor determining lymph nodes statusà Depth of invasion
  • Femoral and inguinal lymph nodes are the sites of regional spread
  • Sheet like growth with infiltrating bands and single cells
  • Often desmoplastic/inflammatory stroma

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

CLASSIFIED BY HPV STATUS:

Microscopic images

questions.text: Choose the incorrect option for Malignant mixed mullerian tumor (MMMT)?
questions.solution:
Biphasic tumor with two components:

1. High grade carcinoma (EPITHELIAL)

2. Sarcoma (Mesenchymal) (Choice B)

  • Sarcoma represents a transdifferentiation (epithelial- mesenchymal transition) of epithelial component during tumor evolution
  • Highly aggressive tumor
  • Typically post menopausal women presenting with vaginal bleeding.
  • Often a large pelvic mass (bulky polypoid) that prolapses out of the cervix in~1/2 of cases
  • Often intimate admixure of both elements.
  • Carcinoma is often serous or endometrioid carcinoma
  • Sarcoma is often high grade non specific sarcoma, but "heterologus" elements can be including:
    • Rhabdomyosarcoma
    • Chondrosarcoma
    • Osteosarcoma
  • Molecular: Frequent Tp53 mutation (choice C)
    • The mutations found in carcinosarcomas involve the same genes that are mutated in endometrial carcinoma, such as PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA, whereas alterations typical of sarcomas are absent,suggesting that these tumors are carcinomas that have acquired the capacity for mesenchymal differentiation.
  • Poor prognosis: Frequent pelvic recurrences and lymph nodes metastases (of carcinomatous component)
    • Outcome is determined primarily by depth of invasion and stage.
    • The only other known prognostic factor: differentiation of the mesenchymal component; patients with tumors that have heterologous mesenchymal components have a poorer prognosis than those whose tumors do not. (Choice D)
    • Overall 5-year survival rates are 25% to 30% for patients with high-stage disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: MMMT, also known as carcinosarcoma, is a rare and highly aggressive tumor that contains both epithelial (carcinomatous) and mesenchymal (sarcomatous) components.

It arises from the female genital tract, most commonly the uterus, but can also occur in the ovary, cervix, or fallopian tube.

questions.text: The lesion of 36 years old female with adnexal mass with high serum Beta HCG value is shown below (gross and microscopic images). Which genetic karyotyping abnormality is seen the most in this lesion?
questions.solution:
COMPLETE HYDATIDIFORM MOLE

Complete mole- Formed by: Anuclear ovum + sperm (either 2 sperm or 1 that replicates) à diploid and diandric with two sets of paternal chromosomes (androgenetic diploidy)

Clinical findings: very high serum hCG (>100k)

Large uterus, bleeding, "snowstorm" on ultrasound

Grossly: Hydropic "grape-like" villi

90% percent have a 46,XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic material of one sperm (a phenomenon called androgenesis).

The remaining 10% result from the fertilization of an empty egg by two sperm; these may have a 46,XX or 46,XY karyotype. In complete moles, the embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified.

Risk of choriocarcinoma: 2.5%

Risk of persistent or invasive mole: 15%

Follow serum hCG for disease monitoring after treatment with medication and surgical removal.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman in the third trimester of her second pregnancy presents with a 1-week history of vaginal bleeding. The patient subsequently gives birth to a healthy female at 35 weeks of gestation. Immediately after delivery, the patient begins to hemorrhage transvaginally. The bleeding cannot be controlled, and the patient undergoes emergency hysterectomy. Examination of the hysterectomy specimen reveals penetration of chorionic villi deep into the myometrium, causing failure of the placental tissue to fully separate from the uterine wall. Which of the following best describes the uteroplacental abnormality seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Abnormal adherence of the placenta to the underlying uterine wall is subclassified according to the depth of villous invasion into the myometrium.

  • PLACENTA ACCRETA: the attachment of villi to the myometrium without further invasion.
  • PLACENTA INCRETA (correct Answer) : villi invading the underlying myometrium.
  • PLACENTA PERCRETA: villi penetrating the full thickness of the uterine wall.
    • Most patients with placenta accretahave a normal pregnancy and delivery. However, bleeding in the third trimester is the most common presenting sign before delivery.
    • In patients with placenta increta and percreta, substantial fragments of placenta may remain adherent to the uterine wall after Delivery and are a source of postpartum hemorrhage.
    • Abruptio placentae (choice B) refers to retroplacental hemorrhage in the absence of clinical hemorrhage. A defi ciency of decidua at the implantation site may result from implantation of the placenta Close to or over the cervix (placenta previa, choice D).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Placenta Accreta Spectrum refers to a group of conditions characterized by abnormal placental attachment to the uterine wall due to a defect in the decidua basalis, leading to varying degrees of placental invasion.

Types:

  1. Placenta Accreta: Placenta attaches directly to the myometrium without intervening decidua.
  2. Placenta Increta: Placenta invades the myometrium.
  3. Placenta Percreta: Placenta penetrates through the myometrium into the serosa and may involve adjacent organs (e.g., bladder).

Reference: https://www.babycenter.com/pregnancy/health-and-safety/placenta-accreta_10407873

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents for a complete physical examination. During the pelvic examination, a 5-cm cystic mass is found in the region of the right ovary. Radiographs show focal calcifications in the mass. The tumor is removed, and the surgical specimen is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MATURE TERATOMA/ DERMOID CYST

  • Tumor of germ cell origin that differentiates toward somatic structures.
  • Most benign teratomas are cystic and are often referred to as dermoid cysts
  • Cystic teratomas are usually found in young women.
  • They may be discovered incidentally, but are occasionally associated with clinically important paraneoplastic syndromes, such as inflammatory limbic encephalitis
  • Bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases. Characteristically it consists of a Gross - unilocular cyst containing hair and sebaceous material.
    • Sectioning reveals a thin wall lined by opaque, gray-white, wrinkled epidermis, frequently with protruding hair shafts.
    • Within the wall, it is common to find grossly evident tooth structures and areas of calcification.
  • Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of stratified squamous Epithelium with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures.
  • In most cases, tissues from other germ layers can be identified, such as cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue.
  • Haploid (postmeiotic) germ cells are believed to Auto-fertilize, yielding diploid tumor cells that are genetically Female (46,XX).
  • Teratocarcinoma (choice D) features immature embryonic tissues and malignant stem cells.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A benign germ cell tumor that arises from totipotent germ cells, capable of differentiating into multiple tissue types from the three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm).

questions.text: 39 Year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of increasing abdominal girth. On physical examination, there is pronounced ascites. Pelvic examination reveals a left adnexal mass. A 6-cm ovarian tumor is removed. The tumor is solid and white. Histologically, it is composed of cells resembling Normal ovarian stroma surrounded by collagen fibers. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FIBROMAS are the most common ovarian stromal tumors,

  • accounting for 75% of all stromal tumors
  • 7% of all ovarian tumors.
  • perimenopausal period
  • benign.
  • Gross: The tumors are solid, firm, and white.
  • Microscopically, the cells resemble the stroma of the normal ovarian cortex, being composed of well-differentiated fibroblasts and variable amounts of collagen.
  • Half of the larger tumors are associated with ascites and, rarely, with ascites and pleural effusions.
  • ovarian tumor + hydrothorax + ascites= MEIGS SYNDROME.
  • Ascites is not a typical clinical feature of the other choices.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

A benign ovarian tumor arising from stromal cells of the ovary.

Part of the sex cord-stromal tumors group.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Pathologic-findings-of-the-ovarian-fibroma-Macroscopic-appearance-showed-a-solid-and_fig5_302594157
